Other General Services - support to civil society
Building on previous collaborative work of the Government of Lesotho and UNDP/UNCDF in the area of decentralization, this project aims to accelerate progress and deepen decentralization in Lesotho.

This project main purpose is to promote decentralized service delivery for social and economic growth through the development of transparent funding mechanisms and by improving the accountability of local authorities.

description.narrative: policy, planning and administration

provider-org.narrative: UNITED NATIONS DEVELOPMENT FUND FOR WOME

description.narrative: 1. Existence of an Investment Policy, trade policy and related policies for inclusive growth and employment creation 2. Existence of the Mining and Minerals Policy, and Legal framework 3. 4. DB ranking, No of days taken to register a business- 9 days; No of people accessing OBFC services Other secondary policies

comment.narrative: 1. No investment and trade policies 2. Mining Rights Act 1967, Mining and Minerals Act 2005, No mining policy 3. Number of employment opportunities and jobs created 4. DB ranking # 162 (out of 189 countries); No of days to register a business – 40 days

1. Draft Trade policy 2. Mining policy and related legal framework
3. 200 women and youth trained in entrepreneurship and 25% of them accessing funds for establishment of own micro and small enterprises
4. Support OBFC for automation of the external trade procedures (ASYCUDA) assessment. Continue to increase number of people accessing OBFC services, and Reduce number of days taken to register a business to 9 days

1.1. The background to the development of the Trade policy has been published, however, due to lack of funding resources, limited coordination capacities within the relevant government ministry, the policy has not been developed yet.
2. The Mining and Minerals Policy was adopted by the GoL. In collaboration with UNECA, the legal framework has also been developed and submitted for drafting of the law for Mining and Minerals extraction in Lesotho.
3. 202 people (164 women and 38 men) were trained in entrepreneurship skills and helped to establish own small and micro enterprises.
4. Assessment for ASYCUDA (Automated System for Customs Data management) completed, with support from UNCTAD. This will further enable systems interfacing for improved number of days taken to register a business. The World Bank DB indicators reports 29days in Lesotho, while OBFC takes 3 days to complete registration processes. At least 22, 000 being 40% more people are using the OBFC services.

1. Support drafting and consultations for the youth policy 3.1. Entrepreneurship training programs for women and youth 3.2. Support improved access to finance; Financial education campaigns; Financial Inclusion ME framework; Finscope MSME 2015; Launch Mobile money ecosystems project

1. National Youth Policy. Lesotho is developing the national Youth Policy with the joint technical support of the UNDP and other UN agencies. The drafting process was inclusive of CSOs and youth-led organizations, and has resulted in draft policy statement, widely validated through all Lesotho’s administrative districts. The policy is envisioned to support civil society organizations, Government of Lesotho and development partners in youth development.
3.2. Supported Money Week 2016 Campaign, through provision of a financial education expert for the MW roundtable discussions to share experiences on development of financial literacy programs and integration into schools’ curriculum. - Finscope MSME 2015 survey was launched. The report was supported in partnership with FinMark Trust. The survey also developed a Lesotho - specific Business Sophistication Measure (BSM) to assess the business operational and management sophistication among Basotho MSMEs, as well as help in business profiling. - National partners supported to attend a regional workshop on inclusive business to support development of the Lesotho pilot project on inclusive business ecosystems. A project documents on Lesotho Scaling Inclusion through Mobile Money (Lesotho SIMM) developed, and to be implemented in partnership with Government of Lesotho, private sector, FinMark Trust and ITC. Due diligence for private sector partners completed, and MOU signed with Econet Lesotho to leverage opportunities in inclusive development.

description.narrative: National capacities of government, civil society and private sector increased to mainstream HIV/AIDs issues into national and local policies and strategies.

participating-org.narrative: JOINT UNITED NATIONS PROGRAMME ON HIV/AIDS

description.narrative: capital of a political entity
Health - policy, planning and administration

provider-org.narrative: JOINT UNITED NATIONS PROGRAMME ON HIV/AIDS
JOINT UNITED NATIONS PROGRAMME ON HIV/AIDS

description.narrative: 1. Existence of NAC, 2. Existence of HIV maintreaming guidelines (per ministry), 3. Improved Global Gender Gap Ranking,

comment.narrative: 1. No National AIDS Coordination Body in place; 2. Draft EIA regulations, 3. Draft HIV and the Law report (Legal Environment Impact Assessment), 4. Draft Public Sector HIV Mainatreaming Guidelines, 5. Draft regulations for TRIPS,

1. Support re-inauguration of NAC (National AIDS Commission), Support implementation of the Public Sector Mainstreaming guidelines, 3.1. Support private sector gender mainstreaming and equity initiatives 3.2 Advocacy on reduced stigma and discrimination associated with HIV and AIDS among the youth and Basotho communities

1. NAC inaugurated, with revised NAC Act, Board of Directors and Strategic Plan, 2. The Government of Lesotho adopted the Public Sector HIV and AIDS mainstreaming guidelines and resuscitated a ministerial coordinating committee to oversee the process. 3.1. Issued a first report towards private sector gender equity initiatives, by showcasing women portraits on roles played by women in different private sector companies, especially in positions that were traditionally held by men. 3.2. Published a 'Take a Pledge" documentary to encourage reduced stigma and discrimination among youth and Basotho communities, and using You Tube and social media, encourage voices and advocacy against HIV and AIDS related stigma and discrimination
1. 2000 people (youth and women) reached through HIV and gender advocacy and campaigns 2. Achieve a gold rating on the gender seal 3. Publish the HIV and the Law report

1. 'Take the pledge campaign' re-launched with the National University of Lesotho, social media and radio. Over 40, 000 youth reached through YouTube, Facebook and radio programs. 2. HIV and the Law report approved by the Ministry of Law and Constitution and was launched. The reports highlights the legal environment relative to the HIV and AIDS response in Lesotho. 3.1. UNDP staff trained on gender mainstreaming to enhance skills and understanding. 3.2. Gender sensitive recruitment tools developed tor validation and integration of gender issues in recruitment.

description.narrative: Bridge the information gap for statistics, and data by building capacities for collection, use and analysis by strengthening the national capacities for ME and statistics.
independent political entity

activity-description.narrative: Ministry of Development Planning (Bureau of Statistics Dept. of ME)

description.narrative: Existence of the MDG reports, Post 2015 agenda, NHDR Annual research reports Statistical reports

comment.narrative: A draft ME framework for NSDP MDG Report 2008 MDG Acceleration Framework (MAF)

1. Publish the NHDR 2014/15 2. Publish MDG 2015 Status Report 3. Continue post 2015 consultations and SDGs mobilization 4. Analysis and publish the Economic Census and Business register report 5. 4 issues of the Quarterly Socio – Economic Policy review publication 6. Design and development of the project on sustainable data and statistics

1. Drafting of the NHDR finalized. The report will be published in 2016. 2. Issued the high level summary report on the status of the MDG 2015. The full report will be published in 2016. 3. SDG mobilization: 3.1. A multi-stakeholder forum for about 60 representatives for government, civil society and private sector on the SDGs processes and domestication of targets 3.2. 400 youth trained on SDGs and processes for effective participation and engagement The Economic Census and Business register report published
1. SDG advocacy and mainstreaming 2. MDG Status Report 2015 3. Support development of the NSDP II 4. Launch the NHDR 5. New project on Lesotho Data developed

1. SDG Advocacy and mainstreaming 1.1. Technical and financial support from the UNDP has facilitated advocacy and mainstreaming of Agenda 2013 in Lesotho resulting in: - SDG Rollout Plan and district level advocacy and prioritization of the SDGs - Capacity building for SDG Sensitization Workshops, district workshops and national sensitization workshops - Development of basic SDG mapping tools against the Agenda 2063, NSDP and Vision 2020. - Resource mobilization through a Kazakhstan partnership for SDG localization and advocacy
1.2. Foresight and scenario planning methodologies for SDGs and NSDP implementation and mainstreaming 1.3. High Level joint Lesotho - UN High Level Roundtable Discussions. Supported hosting of the Government of Lesotho-UN High Level Roundtable Discussions during the UNDG Regional Directors visit to Lesotho from 13-15 July 2016. The discussions highlighted the need to resolve current challenges to economic development and growth, political stability and responses to environmental/climate change effects.
2. MDG reporting. Lesotho developed the MDG Status Report 2016, with the joint UN technical support. 3. National Human Development Report. The Lesotho Human Development Report 2015 was finalized, and launched jointly with the Africa - HDR 2016 and Global HDR 2015, with emphasis on human development, youth and women empowerment .The Lesotho HDR process included engagement of the students of the Limkokwing University of Creative Technology, to design cover pages and chapter breakers for the LHDR. At least 4 students participated in the competition.
4. Lesotho Data for Sustainable Development Project documentation was finalized, and negotiations for project funding with the European Commission in Lesotho, completed. The project will be launched in 2017.

description.narrative: Development of Cornerstone Public Policies and Institutional Capacities to accelerate Sustainable Energy for All (SE4A)
Catalyse investments in renewable energy-based mini-grids and Energy Centres to reduce GHG emissions and contribute to the achievement of Lesotho’s Vision 2020 and SE4All goals.

description.narrative: 1. Emission reductions (in tCO2 over 20 yr timeline). 2. Energy produced (MWh) by RETs. 3. Number of jobs created. 4. Number of beneficiary households in rural areas.

comment.narrative: GHG emissions in the country has increased from 0.76 million tCO2 in 1994 to 1.1 million tCO2 in 2000 and expected to increase to 5.2 million tCO2 by 2030. The present contribution of RETs in the provision of off-grid rural energy services is negligible. No investment taking place in the provision of rural energy services through mini-grids electricity generation.
Launch the SEA4ALL project

The SE4ALL project was launched in November 2016. The objective of the project is to catalyze investment in renewable energy-based mini-grids and Energy Centres to reduce GHG emissions and contribute to the achievement of Lesotho’s Vision 2020 and SE4All goals.

description.narrative: This LDCF - financed project will contribute to overcoming these barriers through strengthening institutional and technical capacities of government institutions to plan for and implement adaptation using an ecosystem management approach
The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to

Total number of disaster risk reduction and/or integrated disaster risk reduction and adaptation plans, and dedicated institutional frameworks and multi-stakeholder coordination mechanisms, are in place

Number of disaster risk reduction and/or integrated disaster risk reduction and adaptation plans, and dedicated institutional frameworks and multi-stakeholder coordination mechanisms, which are gender responsive
total number of legislative or regulatory provisions for DRM (including CRM)
number of legislative or regulatory provisions for DRM (including CRM) that are effective

Increased technical capacity of the Ministry of Forestry, Range and Soil Conservation, and relevant departments to apply up to date climate science for the management of evolving risks and uncertainty linked to climate change
first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: Mohale's Hoek district at Lithipeng, Khoelenya and Thaba- Mokhele Community Councils for sustainable Land rehabilitation initiatives

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness
The use of climate-driven vulnerabilities and cost-effective planning to inform the implementation of the Land Rehabilitation Programme.

comment.narrative: Climate change risks are not integrated into the Land Rehabilitation Programme. Target sites are chosen on an ad hoc basis. Rehabilitation and management measures are not tailored to specific ecosystems

The PMU is established and fully staffed and is functional The Terms of Reference are developed and the following specialists are recruited, CTA, GIS and Socio economic specialists to conduct vulnerability assessments at the Project sites
Project management Unit established Vulnerability assessments carried out

Capacitate government extension personnel and local communities through trainings to enable their effective participation in mainstreaming climate change (CC) into community plans and CC policy development process.

Strengthened ecosystem conservation by capacitating local authorities including chiefs on conflict management and application of environmental laws and extension personnel Climate-Smart practices including compilation of a typology of Climate Smart technologies. Carried out baseline studies including Socio-Economic survey, Land degradation mapping and Climate Risk assessment aimed at informing decision-making and development of policies. Established learning labs in 3 community councils to foster adoption of disaster and climate risk measures by communities.
